question:
In humans the neck is joined by the head by which of the following joints?

SSC CHSL 09/03/2023 (4th shift)
option_1: Ball and socket joint
solution:
• The joint that connects the head to the neck in humans is called a pivotal joint.
  • It allows the head to rotate from side to side, such as when we nod "no".
  • This joint is located between the first cervical vertebra (atlas) and the second cervical vertebra (axis).
  • The pivotal joint allows rotational movement around a single axis.

Additional Information:

  • Ball and socket joint: Allows movement in all directions (e.g., shoulder, hip)
  • Hinge joint: Allows back-and-forth movement like a door (e.g., knee, elbow)
  • Fixed joint: No movement (e.g., bones of the skull)

question:
Which among the following is a flat bone?

SSC CHSL 20/03/2023 (1st shift)
solution:
• Ribs are classified as flat bones in the human skeletal system.
  • Flat bones are thin, flattened, and usually curved, designed to provide protection and surface area for muscle attachment.
  • The ribs form the rib cage, which protects vital organs like the heart and lungs.
  • Other examples of flat bones include the sternum, skull bones, and scapula.

Additional Information:

  • Ankle and wrist bones: Classified as short bones, provide limited movement
  • Pelvic bones: Considered irregular bones due to their complex shape

question:
The fluid present between joints, that makes the movement of joints easy, is called:

SSC MTS 08/10/2021 (Evening)
solution:
• The fluid present between joints that lubricates and eases movement is called synovial fluid.
  • It is secreted by the synovial membrane present in freely movable joints.
  • Synovial fluid reduces friction between the articular cartilage of joints during movement.
  • It also nourishes the cartilage and acts as a shock absorber.

Additional Information:

  • Bursae: Fluid-filled sacs that reduce friction at joints
  • Cartilage: Smooth tissue covering the ends of bones in joints
  • Tendon: Connects muscle to bone, not involved in lubrication

question:
In which of the following parts of the human body is the masseter muscle located?

SSC MTS 13/10/2021 (Afternoon)
solution:
• The masseter muscle is located in the jaw region of the human body.
  • It is one of the strongest muscles in terms of force and plays a key role in chewing (mastication).
  • The masseter helps in raising the lower jaw (mandible) to close the mouth.
  • It connects the zygomatic bone (cheekbone) to the mandible (lower jawbone).

Additional Information:

  • It is a facial muscle and is activated when we bite or clench our teeth.
  • Disorders in the masseter muscle can cause jaw pain or temporomandibular joint issues (TMJ).

question:
Which of the following is a complex substance that provides structural strength to plants?

SSC MTS 18/10/2021 (1st shift)
solution:
• Cellulose is a complex carbohydrate (polysaccharide) that provides structural strength to plant cell walls.
  • It is composed of long chains of glucose molecules bonded together.
  • Cellulose gives rigidity to the plant cell wall, helping plants maintain their shape and structure.
  • It is the most abundant organic polymer on Earth and is not digestible by humans.

Additional Information:

  • Xylem: Transports water and minerals from roots to other parts of the plant
  • Phloem: Transports food (glucose) from leaves to other plant parts
  • Cytoplasm: Jelly-like fluid inside cells where cellular activities occur

question:
The human shoulder joint is an example of a _________ joint.

SSC MTS 02/11/2021 (1st shift)
solution:
• The human shoulder joint is a classic example of a ball and socket joint.
  • In this joint, the ball-like head of the humerus (upper arm bone) fits into the socket of the scapula (shoulder blade).
  • It allows movement in all directions: forward, backward, sideways, and circular.
  • This type of joint provides maximum range of motion among all joint types.

Additional Information:

  • Fixed joint: No movement (e.g., skull bones)
  • Pivotal joint: Allows rotational movement (e.g., neck)
  • Hinge joint: Allows back-and-forth movement (e.g., knee, elbow)

question:
The vertebrae are a part of which of the following body systems in humans?

SSC CGL 17/08/2021 (Afternoon)
solution:
• The vertebrae are a part of the spinal cord system, specifically forming the vertebral column (backbone).
  • They are small, interlocking bones that protect the spinal cord, which runs through the vertebral canal.
  • The vertebral column provides structural support, helps in body movement, and protects the central nervous system.
  • In humans, there are 33 vertebrae grouped into cervical, thoracic, lumbar, sacral, and coccygeal regions.

Additional Information:

  • The spinal cord is part of the central nervous system (CNS).
  • The vertebrae are critical for maintaining posture and flexibility of the body.

question:
How many bones are there in the human hand?

SSC CHSL 13/04/2021 (Afternoon)
solution:
• There are 27 bones in the human hand.
  • These bones are categorized into three groups:
    • Carpals (wrist bones) – 8
    • Metacarpals (palm bones) – 5
    • Phalanges (finger bones) – 14
  • These bones work together to allow the hand to perform fine motor skills, grip, and flexibility.

Additional Information:

  • The hand is one of the most dexterous and complex parts of the human body.
  • Phalanges are further divided into proximal, middle, and distal for each finger (except the thumb, which has only two).

question:
Which of the following is the largest dental tissue?

SSC CHSL 11/08/2021 (Evening)
solution:
• Dentin is the largest dental tissue in the human tooth structure.
  • It lies beneath the enamel and surrounds the pulp cavity.
  • Dentin is a hard, yellowish tissue that provides bulk and strength to the tooth.
  • It is less hard than enamel but harder than bone, and it contains microscopic tubules that can transmit sensations.

Additional Information:

  • Enamel: Hardest substance in the human body, covers the outer surface of the tooth
  • Pulp: Soft tissue at the center of the tooth containing nerves and blood vessels
  • Root: Part of the tooth embedded in the jawbone, anchors the tooth

question:
Bone cells are embedded in a hard matrix that is composed of:

RRB Group-D 19/09/2022 (Shift-III)
solution:
• Bone cells (osteocytes) are embedded in a hard, mineralized matrix.
  • This matrix is primarily composed of calcium and phosphorus.
  • These minerals provide bones with hardness and rigidity.
  • The main component of the matrix is calcium phosphate, mostly in the form of hydroxyapatite.
  • This structure allows bones to support the body and protect vital organs.

Additional Information:

  • Calcium and phosphorus are stored in bones and released into the bloodstream as needed.
  • Bone matrix also contains collagen fibers that provide flexibility and tensile strength.

question:
What is the cause of muscle cramps?

RRB Group-D 17/09/2022 (Shift-II)
option_1: Excessive excitation of neuromuscular junctions
option_2: Insufficiency of oxygen supply to muscles
option_3: Fatigue and weakness of the body
option_4: Low glucose level in the blood (hypoglycemia)
solution:
• Muscle cramps occur when muscle fibers contract involuntarily and forcefully.
  • A common cause is insufficient oxygen supply to the muscles during prolonged or intense activity.
  • When oxygen is lacking, muscles switch to anaerobic respiration, producing lactic acid.
  • Accumulation of lactic acid causes pain and muscle stiffness.
  • Cramps are more frequent during heavy exercise, dehydration, or poor circulation.

Additional Information:

  • Proper hydration and stretching help prevent cramps.
  • Potassium, calcium, and magnesium also play a key role in muscle contraction and relaxation.

question:
What is the difference between striated and smooth muscle cells?

RRB Group-D 12/09/2022 (Shift-II)
option_1: Striated muscles lack nuclei while smooth muscles are binucleated
option_2: Smooth muscles are not connected to the nerves while striated muscles are connected.
option_3: All striated muscles work by reflex action as compared to smooth muscles.
option_4: Smooth muscles cannot contract at will, while voluntary muscles contract at will.
solution:
• Striated muscles (also called skeletal muscles) are voluntary muscles, meaning they can be controlled consciously.
  • Smooth muscles are involuntary muscles and cannot be controlled at will.
  • Striated muscles show alternating light and dark bands (striations) under a microscope.
  • Smooth muscles lack striations and are found in internal organs like intestines and blood vessels.
  • The correct difference: Smooth muscles contract involuntarily, while striated muscles contract voluntarily.

Additional Information:

  • Striated muscles are multinucleated and attached to bones.
  • Smooth muscles are uninucleated and controlled by the autonomic nervous system.

question:
Movement in most of the animals is a coordinated activity of which of the following system/systems?

RRB Group-D 22/08/2022 (Shift-I)
option_1: Only skeletal and nervous systems
option_3: Muscular skeletal and nervous systems
solution:
• Movement in animals is a coordinated process involving multiple body systems.
  • The muscular system provides the force required for movement.
  • The skeletal system acts as a framework that supports and allows movement.
  • The nervous system controls and coordinates the actions of muscles and bones through signals.
  • Therefore, movement is possible through the combined efforts of muscular, skeletal, and nervous systems.

Additional Information:

  • Voluntary movements are consciously controlled by the central nervous system.
  • Involuntary movements like reflexes are also regulated by the nervous system.

question:
Which of the following statements is correct about striated muscles?

RRB Group-D 28/09/2022 (Shift-I)
option_1: Cells are long, cylindrical, non-tapering and are unbranched
option_2: Prominent light and dark bands are present
option_3: Cells are long with tapering ends and are unbranched
option_4: Cells are non-tapering and cylindrical in shape and are branched
solution:
• Striated muscles are also called skeletal muscles and are under voluntary control.
  • They show alternating light and dark bands (striations) under the microscope.
  • These bands are due to the arrangement of actin and myosin filaments.
  • The muscle cells are long, cylindrical, multinucleated, and unbranched.
  • Hence, the correct statement is that prominent light and dark bands are present.

Additional Information:

  • Striated muscles are responsible for body movement and are attached to bones.
  • They fatigue quickly as they require continuous energy for contraction.

question:
You get cramps after participating in a 400 m race. Which option best explains the reason for the same?

RRB Group-D 29/08/2022 (Shift-III)
option_1: Lack of oxygen and pyruvate is converted to glucose
option_2: Lack of oxygen and pyruvate is converted to ethanol
option_3: Enough oxygen and pyruvate converted to lactic acid
option_4: Lack of oxygen and pyruvate to lactic acid
solution:
• During a 400 m race, the muscles require energy faster than oxygen can be supplied.
  • This results in anaerobic respiration, where oxygen is insufficient for aerobic respiration.
  • Under these conditions, pyruvate is converted into lactic acid instead of entering the mitochondria.
  • Lactic acid buildup causes pain, tightness, and muscle cramps.
  • Thus, the correct explanation is: Lack of oxygen and conversion of pyruvate to lactic acid.

Additional Information:

  • Anaerobic respiration occurs in the cytoplasm, not mitochondria.
  • Lactic acid fermentation is a short-term adaptation to energy demands during intense activity.
  • Excess lactic acid reduces muscle pH, contributing to fatigue.
  • Once oxygen becomes available, lactic acid is transported to the liver and converted back to pyruvate or glucose.
  • Such cramps are common in short-duration, high-intensity exercises like sprinting or fast cycling.

question:
The movement of food in the alimentary canal is brought about by the smooth muscles in the body. Which of the following options has all the organs having smooth muscles?

RRB Group-D 02/09/2022 (Shift-I)
option_1: Iris of the eye, bronchi of lungs, ureters
option_2: Blood vessels, ureters, bones
option_3: Bones, ureters, bronchi of lungs
option_4: Heart, iris of the eye, bones
solution:
• Smooth muscles are involuntary muscles found in the walls of internal organs and help in activities like movement of food, blood flow, and contraction of airways.
  • These muscles are present in iris of the eye (controls pupil size), bronchi of lungs (regulate airflow), and ureters (propel urine from kidneys to bladder).
  • Bones and heart contain different types of muscle tissues – skeletal and cardiac respectively, not smooth.
  • Hence, the correct answer includes all three organs that contain smooth muscles: iris, bronchi, and ureters.

Additional Information:

  • Smooth muscles are uninucleated and non-striated.
  • They contract slowly and rhythmically, and are controlled by the autonomic nervous system.
  • They are also found in the walls of intestines, stomach, urinary bladder, and blood vessels.

question:
Which one of the following statement is NOT correct?

RRB NTPC Stage-I 15/03/2021 (Shift-II)
option_1: The stapes in the middle ear is the smallest bone of the human skeleton.
option_2: Appendix is a vestigial organ present in the human body.
option_3: Bone marrow produces red blood cells in the human body.
option_4: The human vertebral column has vertebrae.
solution:
• Option (a): Correct – Stapes is indeed the smallest bone in the human body, located in the middle ear.
  • Option (b): Correct – The appendix is a vestigial organ, meaning it no longer serves a significant function in digestion.
  • Option (c): Correct – Bone marrow is responsible for producing red blood cells (RBCs), along with white blood cells and platelets.
  • Option (d): Incorrect/NOT correct – The human vertebral column contains vertebrae, so this statement is factually correct, but since the question asks for a NOT correct option, this seems to be a key error in the question/answer key.

Correct interpretation: If we accept that all four options are factually correct, then none of the options are technically incorrect, meaning the given answer may be based on a misreading.

But assuming the intent was to test understanding, there is no error in (d). So answer (d) is not the correct choice for "NOT correct."

Hence, question key seems wrong unless there's a language interpretation error.

question:
In humans, the tissue that connects the muscles to bones is called:

RRB JE 14/12/2014
solution:
• In the human body, tendons are the connective tissues that attach muscles to bones.
  • They are composed of dense connective tissue made mostly of collagen fibers.
  • Tendons help transmit the force generated by muscle contraction to the bones, causing movement.
  • They are strong but not very flexible, which helps maintain stability during motion.
  • This differentiates tendons from ligaments, which connect bone to bone.

Additional Information:

  • Axon is part of a neuron, not connective tissue.
  • Femur is the longest bone in the human body, not a connective tissue.
  • Fibers refer to structures in muscle or connective tissues but are not a specific tissue type.

question:
A tendon made of:

RRB ALP & Tec. 31/08/2018 (Shift-II)
option_2: Elastic connective tissue fibers
option_3: Inelastic connective tissue fibers
option_4: Elastic & inelastic connective tissue fibers
solution:
• A tendon is a tough, flexible band of connective tissue that connects muscles to bones.
  • It is primarily composed of collagen fibers only, which are strong, inelastic, and fibrous proteins.
  • These collagen fibers allow tendons to resist tension and transmit force efficiently.
  • Tendons do not contain elastic fibers, which makes them less stretchable but highly durable.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is: collagen fiber only.

Additional Information:

  • Collagen provides tensile strength and structural integrity to tendons.
  • Unlike ligaments (which may contain some elastic fibers), tendons are completely non-elastic to ensure precise muscle-to-bone force transmission.

question:
What is the total number of bones in the skeleton of an average adult human?

RRB JE 14/12/2014
solution:
• An average adult human skeleton consists of 206 bones.
  • At birth, humans have about 270 bones, but many of these fuse together during growth.
  • The bones are grouped into two main categories: Axial skeleton (80 bones) and Appendicular skeleton (126 bones).
  • These bones provide support, protection, and aid in movement.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is 206 bones in an adult.

Additional Information:

  • The axial skeleton includes the skull, vertebral column, and rib cage.
  • The appendicular skeleton includes limbs and girdles (shoulder and pelvic).
  • Bone count may slightly vary in some individuals due to accessory bones.

question:
The ___________ has abundant white fibres.

RRB ALP & Tec. 20/08/2018 (Shift-I)
solution:
• Tendons are connective tissues that attach muscles to bones.
  • They are composed mainly of abundant white collagen fibers, which are strong, dense, and inelastic.
  • These white fibers give tendons tensile strength, allowing them to efficiently transmit force during muscle contraction.
  • Unlike ligaments (which have more elastic fibers), tendons are less flexible but more durable.
  • Hence, the correct answer is tendons.

Additional Information:

  • White fibers are rich in collagen, while yellow fibers (seen in ligaments) are rich in elastin.
  • Tendons are found at joints, helping in movement and support.
  • They are poorly vascularized, hence heal slowly after injury.

question:
In human body, vertebrae is part of:

RRB NTPC Stage-I 27/04/2016 (Shift-II)
solution:
• Vertebrae are the individual bones that form the vertebral column (spine) in the human body.
  • These bones protect and support the spinal cord, which passes through the vertebral canal.
  • The vertebral column runs from the base of the skull to the pelvis, providing structural support.
  • While the spinal cord is part of the nervous system, the vertebrae are skeletal components that encase and protect it.
  • Hence, vertebrae are considered a part of the spinal cord system anatomically.

Additional Information:

  • An adult human typically has 33 vertebrae, grouped as cervical (7), thoracic (12), lumbar (5), sacral (5 fused), and coccygeal (4 fused).
  • The vertebral column also allows flexibility and movement of the torso and back.

question:
Which is the longest bone in the human body?

RRB NTPC Stage-I 21/01/2021 (Shift-II)
solution:
• The femur, or thigh bone, is the longest and strongest bone in the human body.
  • It extends from the hip joint to the knee joint, supporting the weight of the body during standing, walking, and running.
  • It plays a crucial role in locomotion and forms part of the appendicular skeleton.
  • The femur is also involved in blood cell formation through the bone marrow inside it.
  • Hence, the correct answer is femur.

Additional Information:

  • Patella is the kneecap – a small, round bone in front of the knee joint.
  • Sternum is the breastbone located in the center of the chest.
  • Tibia is the second longest bone, located in the lower leg, but shorter than the femur.

question:
Select the wrong pair of bone and related part of the human body from the given alternatives.

RRB NTPC Stage-I 23/07/2021 (Shift-II)
solution:
The Correct Answer is: (c) Carpal bone – Neck

Explanation:

(c) Carpal bones are eight small bones arranged in two rows in the wrist (carpus) region, connecting the hand to the forearm. They help in wrist movement and stability. They are not related to the neck in any way.

  • (a) Maxilla is the upper jaw bone, forming the upper dental arch and part of the nasal cavity and eye socket.
  • (b) Patella, also known as the kneecap, is a triangular bone in front of the knee joint. It protects the knee and connects thigh muscles to the tibia.
  • (d) Ulna is one of the two long bones of the forearm (the other is radius). It runs from the elbow to the smallest finger side, forming a major part of the hand and wrist structure.

Hence, carpal bones are wrongly paired with neck in this question.

question:
Approximately, how many bones are there in a child’s body at the time of birth?

RRB NTPC Stage-I 30/01/2021 (Shift-II)
solution:
• At the time of birth, a child has approximately 300 bones in their body.
  • These bones are separate and more flexible to allow growth and ease of movement during birth.
  • As the child grows, some bones gradually fuse together to form larger, stronger bones.
  • By adulthood, the number reduces to 206 bones due to this fusion process.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is 300 bones.

Additional Information:

  • Major bone fusions occur in the skull and spine during childhood and adolescence.
  • The flexibility of infant bones is due to the presence of cartilage, which later ossifies into bone.
  • This fusion helps in developing a stronger and more stable skeletal system for adult functions.

question:
__________ is not a human bone joint.

RRB NTPC Stage-I 19/04/2016 (Shift-III)
solution:
• Ball and socket, gliding, and saddle are all types of joints found in the human skeletal system.
  • These joints allow different types of movement between bones.
  • Ball and socket joint (e.g., shoulder, hip) allows rotational movement.
  • Gliding joints (e.g., between wrist bones) allow sliding movement.
  • Saddle joints (e.g., thumb joint) allow flexion, extension, and limited rotation.
  • Macro is not a type of joint—it is a prefix meaning large or big, and has no anatomical reference to joints.

Additional Information:

  • The study of joints is called arthrology.
  • Joints are classified functionally as immovable (fibrous), slightly movable (cartilaginous), and freely movable (synovial).
  • The human body has around 360 joints, of various types.

question:
Which is the hardest substance in the human body?

RRB JE 23/05/2019 (Shift-I)
solution:
• The hardest substance in the human body is tooth enamel.
  • It is the outermost layer of the tooth and functions to protect the inner layers from decay, damage, and wear.
  • Tooth enamel is made up of 96% minerals, primarily calcium phosphate in the form of hydroxyapatite.
  • It is harder than bones, fingernails, and cartilage but is also brittle and cannot regenerate once destroyed.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is tooth enamel.

Additional Information:

  • Fingernails are made of keratin, which is tough but not as hard as enamel.
  • Skull bones are strong and dense, but not the hardest.
  • Knee cap (patella) is a bone, which is softer than enamel.

question:
There are 29 bones in the human head. Which of the following classifications is correct?

RRB NTPC Stage-I 03/04/2021 (Shift-I)
option_1: Forehead-8, Facial-14, Ear-4, Hyoid-3
option_2: Forehead-8, Facial-14, Ear-6, Hyoid-1
option_3: Forehead-8, Facial-12, Ear-6, Hyoid-3
option_4: Forehead-8, Facial-12, Ear-8, Hyoid-1
solution:
• The human head contains a total of 29 bones, which can be categorized as follows:
    • Cranial bones (Forehead/Skull): 8 bones
    • Facial bones: 14 bones
    • Ear bones (Auditory ossicles): 6 bones (3 in each ear – malleus, incus, stapes)
    • Hyoid bone: 1 bone (supports the tongue and is not directly attached to any other bone)
  • This classification adds up to: 8 (skull) + 14 (face) + 6 (ear) + 1 (hyoid) = 29 bones
  • Therefore, the correct classification is: Forehead-8, Facial-14, Ear-6, Hyoid-1

Additional Information:

  • Cranial bones include: frontal, parietal (2), occipital, temporal (2), sphenoid, and ethmoid.
  • The hyoid bone is unique as it does not articulate with any other bone.
  • Ear ossicles are the smallest bones in the body, located in the middle ear.

question:
Which part of the human body is formed by the fusing of the ilium, ischium and the pubis?

RRB NTPC Stage-I 22/01/2021 (Shift-I)
solution:
• The ilium, ischium, and pubis are three bones that fuse together during development to form a single structure.
  • These three bones form the hip bone or coxal bone, a key part of the pelvic girdle.
  • The hip bone supports the weight of the upper body and connects the spine to the lower limbs.
  • Fusion of these bones occurs around puberty to create a strong, stable structure for movement and balance.
  • Hence, the correct answer is hip bone.

Additional Information:

  • Each side of the pelvis contains one hip bone, and together they form the pelvic cavity.
  • The hip bone articulates with the femur at the acetabulum, a socket formed at the junction of the three bones.
  • The pelvis also protects internal organs like the bladder and reproductive organs.

question:
What are the bones around the chest called?

RRB NTPC Stage-I 05/04/2016 (Shift-II)
solution:
• The bones surrounding the chest are called ribs.
  • These form the rib cage, which protects vital organs such as the heart and lungs.
  • The rib cage consists of 12 pairs of ribs, connected to the thoracic vertebrae at the back.
  • Most ribs are also connected to the sternum (breastbone) via cartilage, allowing flexibility during breathing.
  • Hence, the correct answer is ribs.

Additional Information:

  • The first 7 pairs are called true ribs (directly attached to the sternum).
  • The next 3 pairs are false ribs (indirectly attached).
  • The last 2 pairs are floating ribs (not attached to the sternum at all).
